article.title: Fixed points and the spontaneous breaking of scale invariance

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the different colored lines in Figure 1 represent?
choices: Different values of the dimensionless potential u\'.
Different values of the rescaled field ρ.
Different values of the free parameter c, which characterizes the fixed point solutions.
Different values of the quartic coupling λ.

multiple_choice_question.text: What distinguishes the physically viable fixed point solutions (full lines) from the unphysical ones (dotted and dashed lines)?
choices: The number of relevant directions at the fixed point.
The sign of the sextic coupling τ.
Whether the fixed point solutions have turning points in the regime with positive or negative u\'.
The value of the critical exponent ν.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 3, what is the significance of the parameter Δ?
choices: It represents the difference in the value of the sextic coupling between the weak coupling fixed point and the Wilson-Fisher fixed point.
It represents the shift applied to the Wilson-Fisher fixed point solution to obtain the two branches of the weak coupling fixed point.
It represents the value of the rescaled field ρ at the turning point of the weak coupling fixed point solution.
It represents the difference in the value of the critical exponent ν between the weak coupling fixed point and the Wilson-Fisher fixed point.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 5, what does the thick red line connecting the BMB fixed point to the Wilson-Fisher fixed point represent?
choices: A line of fixed points with vanishing quartic coupling.
The boundary between the symmetric and symmetry broken phases.
A separatrix indicating the flow towards the Wilson-Fisher fixed point.
A trajectory representing the flow of the vacuum expectation value.
